an10.33:4.1: “Sir, how many qualities should a mendicant have to be agreed on as a judge?”
an10.33:4.2: “Upāli, a mendicant should have ten qualities to be agreed on as a judge.
an10.33:4.4: It’s when a mendicant is ethical,
an10.33:4.5: restrained in the List of Rules, and has appropriate behavior and means of collecting alms. Seeing danger in the slightest flaw, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an10.33:4.6: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and understanding them with right view.
an10.33:4.7: Both lists of rules have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well judged in both the rules and accompanying material.
an10.33:4.8: They’re firm in the training, not shaky.
an10.33:4.9: When there are opposing parties, they’re able to persuade, advocate, and convince them, make them see the other side and trust each other.
an10.33:4.10: They’re skilled in raising and settling disciplinary issues.
an10.33:4.11: They know what a disciplinary issue is.
an10.33:4.12: They know how a disciplinary issue originates.
an10.33:4.13: They know how a disciplinary issue ceases.
an10.33:4.14: They know the practical way leading to the cessation of a disciplinary issue.
an10.33:4.15: A mendicant should have these ten qualities to be agreed on as a judge.”
